comments.commentBody:
Of course it wasn't Woodstock. There were way more people at Woodstock than at Trump's inauguration. Whole viewing stands completely empty. Trump organizers were on the Metro trying to hand out tickets to prime viewing stands, and yet the stands were still empty. I hope Congress notices how little support Trump has from the public and acts accordingly.
For photos of the empty stands during the parade look here:
http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/01/20/inaugu...

Linda, ever the optimist! As though Congress (today giggling throughout the proceedings in their delight at having locked up all branches of government), would take even a split second to consider whether they had the citizens behind them. Why would they bother with gerrymandering, or with stonewalling President Obama, if that was their motivation?

I hope that Congress notices how little support Trump has from the public. Really? So, Congress should pursue the agenda of Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell? The end of Social Security, privatization of Medicare?

I'm sure Congress does notice and it doesn't give me comfort.

Linda,
It was raining and the parade was held in Washingon DC.

The working people of America, who voted for and stand by, President Trump could not come. We pay for our own entertainment, and do not need the poltical class spending our own money on Washington's fun parties.

Think on these things?
Voters vote, and we are watching very closely who really represents us, and our interests. Buy a ticket to a concert and pay for your own entertainment. Small government does not pay for that for you anymore.

Mr. Luettgen:

Which do you think will reduce the 780 homicides in Chicago in 2016.
Looser gun safety laws as the NRA and Trump want or stricter gun safety laws that are uniform thru out the US so that people who get guns in states with lax gun laws can not bring these guns into Chicago.

What were the minimum wage and the unemployment rate when the Bush Great Recession began.
What are these quantities now.

First order of business for President P. Grabber the First: signing a decree ending the "disaster" called Obamacare without specifying what exactly would be ending or when exactly it would end or what exactly he'll replace it with (if anything).  But we can all rest assured that by now all violent criminal activity has come to an end- along with all instances of Islamic terrorism- because The Donald has said that it would.  So anyone who now claims that he/she has been beaten up, raped or shot is obviously a liar and should therefore be ignored or prosecuted (or beaten up, raped or shot).  And as soon as he begins to bring home all of the jobs he's outsourced to China, Mexico and Slovenia our new hero of America's working class can start to make good on his promise to bring home all of the jobs that have been outsourced abroad.  If any of this sounds as though it was previously imagined by Lewis Carroll please don't report me to the plagiarism police. It may well be that I fell asleep while watching Mr. Trump fire Latoya Jackson on Celebrity Apprentice and have been dreaming ever since.
Don't you WISH you had been dreaming ever since--i.e. that you (and we) could wake up from this horror?

He is ending the mandate that helps redistribute money from healthy workers to the insurance companies to pay for non-catastrophic medical needs for so many others.

Means tested plans are one thing; asking the rest of us to pick up Sandra Fluke's birth control was another.. Remember her? Trump voters do!

Roger, I'm reminded of a scene in "The Lion in Winter."

Prince John: A knife! He's got a knife!
Eleanor: Of course he has a knife, he always has a knife, we all have knives! It's 1183 and we're barbarians! How clear we make it. Oh, my piglets, we are the origins of war: not history's forces, nor the times, nor justice, nor the lack of it, nor causes, nor religions, nor ideas, nor kinds of government, nor any other thing. We are the killers. We breed wars. We carry it like syphilis inside. Dead bodies rot in field and stream because the living ones are rotten. For the love of God, can't we love one another just a little - that's how peace begins. We have so much to love each other for. We have such possibilities, my children. We could change the world."

At the time I saw that play the first time, in the 1960s, the line seemed comic.

In the context of our times it seems prescient and not funny at all. We live in a moment when more of us have decided no longer try to change the world, and maybe even take up war again.

No one can convince me that's progress. Why Northern Ireland and Scotland remain in league with London is a total mystery to me. The Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland could enter into an Articles of Confederation agreement, recognizing the Stormont agreement and accommodating it, and abandon ruined England for the EU. Scotland could leave to.

Just because others have kept England from the rocks before doesn't obligate anyone to join them this time.

Scotland and Northern Ireland probably will leave but not in a timescale of 2019 when we are out of the EU.

Scotland referendum of 2014 gave a 55:45 vote to stay in U.K. Any polling suggests views have not moved much since but like with Brexit, older voters went for status quo and younger ones for Independance, it is likely there will be a majority for Independance in the 2020's.

In Ireland the North is still split on the Nationlist / Unionist battles of the 20th century, the census of 2021 is likely for the first time to show a nationalist majority but a border poll immediately on a possible 51:49 demographic split would be incredibly contentious, but a 2030's poll was looking likely for a united Ireland we now risk a fight over border controls from 2019 bringing back the bad days of the 1980's.

I got Plantagenet warts, too! When Dangereuse met Troubadour.

"I know. You know I know. I know you know I know. Henry knows we know and he knows we know it! We are a knowledgeable family." Gregory on his mother suggesting they all kill Henry with that knife. How did that family make it all the way to Richard III? Villainy.

I hope Scotland and Ireland leave England on her own to think over the wisdom of her stupidity. What would Eleanore have been without Aquitaine? Surely not queen of BOTH France and England.

March strong njglea!!! March for all women who cannot be there except in spirit, I being one of them. March with all the heart you have shown in your comments supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton, the woman who should have been inaugurated Jan. 20, 2017.
That chant of "lock her up" originated with djt and it is disgraceful that Hillary had to endure hearing those words. But, she is the epitome of a strong woman and my admiration for her has grown ever larger after election 2016.
March with a strong heart njglea and all women who are participating across the USA on Saturday.
The lack of attendees along the Inaugural Parade route is striking.  This is the smallest turnout that I' ever seen at an Inauguration.

Re: "Easy to criticize the man while sipping your lattes in a NY high rise while us "deplorables" struggle in the heartland."

Don't be so ego-centric 1515732 Wales,wi -- there are people struggling everywhere including in NY.

I guess the only non-ironic brag he might have made would have been to say," I have just appointed the most ethical cabinet ever."

That would have then been the time and place for genius Rick Perry to remark,"oops."

It would be a lot easier to listen to Donald Trump if every adjective out of his mouth wasn't a superlative or a superlative pejorative. But then again I guess it's kind of fitting that the man who keeps channeling his inner Dickens would have us all sum up today as "it was the best of times (for Trumpians), it was the worst of times (for the rest of us)".
That Dicksonian reference would go right over his head. Among all his other failings he's practically illiterate.

@Richard:  Have you actually heard any kids (let alone millions of them) complaining that they can't find jobs because of a raise in the minimum wage?  And "first rung" jobs?  My nephew, a recent college graduate, is already earning about as much at the beginning of his career as I earned at the end of mine.  What those unemployed kids need is a good education (preferably resulting in a college degree and preferably without the backbreaking debt that anyone not born into wealth is likely to be saddled with).  They may also need to pull up stakes and move to an urban center where those first rung jobs are generally to be found.  What they don't need- and don't want- are jobs whose existence depend upon maintaining an unlivable minimum wage.

"Trump was going more for Nuremberg Rally than Woodstock"

Karen, let's be fair = maybe in view of the Putin connection, the whiff is less of National Socialism than of the Soviet variety.

One of his first executive orders was for a new Patriots' Day. He has already expressed his fondness for military parades, Soviet- or North Korean- style, and perhaps sees himself using the day to review the troops and their latest military hardware like the old Soviet leaders at the October Revolution parades. His mentor Putin, he who turned seamlessly from Communist KGB chief to super-capitalist autocrat, could coach him in details like how to dress for the occasion. Having never served he couldn't model Stalin's military uniform, but he could project a power-image by going with a heavy winter overcoat à la Brezhnev. So our Great Leader would pick a cold month for his new date on the calendar - perhaps January 20 to commemorate his swearing in.

And while he's at it, he might be tempted to rename the part of Pennsylvania Avenue fronting the White House as Red Square, in honor of the color of the political map of the United States, if only by acreage.

A little under half of the American population voted for Trump? That's pretty off!

We have a total population of 320 million. Trump got 63 million. Clinton got 65.8 million. 60% of eligible voters actually voted. That remaining 40% of eligible voters who sat home represents another sizable segment of the population.

So no, Trump did not win the votes of a little under half the population of the United States.

I saw a few moments of the inauguration this morning, and just before being sworn in watching his face, he did not smile once. One would think someone getting sworn in to be pres would very happy, not him. His smile if has one looks more like a grimace, the mark of a sociopath, unable to smile, laugh at himself, enjoys lording over others, making himself the object of his adoration.

Oh those rusting factories are going to be brought back, like the Packard Plant in Detroit that has been rusting away for years. Auto assembly line jobs, it no longer takes four people to put the tires on, a robot does that. the jobs will require technical skills those laid off workers do not have.

I worked in a plant that made printed wire boards for F18 radar, it was assembly line work, most of the people were from the lower income parts of town. But I saw them leaving in pretty nice cars at night, and they were happy. Talking to them, I found they had bought an extra home and were renting it out, their kids were going to USC, UCLA , Stanford. They were prepared for the future. That is the antithesis of the Midwest unemployed factory workers, a cultural difference. their kids were not going to follow on the assembly line, they were going to be professionals. They recognized the value of education.

Trump see gloom and doom, he is going to make this a lawful country, I have to remind you, Nazi Germany was a country of laws, any criminal was executed, it did not take much to be a criminal.
That was Al Frankton who observed that Trump never laughs. A man who knows something about laughter. Another thing we are going to miss about our ex First Couple. Sigh.

He will smile when the work is done.
This one, he takes the jobs seriously.

Party on Dem friends.
Spend it like it's neverending!
Paul Ryan's smirk complemented Trump's glower. They're team building.

The unfortunate genius of Trump logic is that today he can paint a dark, haunting vision of America. "Carnage."  If the economy, stock market and immigration rates stay the course, he can turn around and claim that he alone has made "America great again."

He's a good con man, and he's figured out that there is an America that responds to root bigotries and does not care about objective fact.

He has already been credited with turning the stock market around.

Mind you - the DOW that was at 7,900 when Obama was elected, and at 19,000 by the time of Trump's election.

To a bigot Obama nearly tripping the stock market - does not make them feel better about America.

But if the market goes up by 5% during the Trump admin - they will declare victory.

Rajiv,

what does it matter who takes the credit, if America IS great again?
But the stock market and immigration rates won't help the disenfranchised one little bit.

Socrates - this time it's worse than merely removing solar panels.  As the Times reports elsewhere, the barbarians have begun purging climate data from government records.  Hardware can be replaced.  Data, once lost, cannot.

David, trump does actually smile sometimes. Anyone can put that on; I suspect his smiles are nearly always of the gotcha variety. I can't remember who it was, but someone quite familiar with trump observed recently that he doesn't laugh, ever.

Kellyanne admonished us to not pay attention to his words but to what's in his heart. Well, if his expressions of amusement are a window to his heart, it's a very cold one.

This morning I saw an unsmiling demagogue telling his followers how bad this country is. That their jobs have been "stolen" by other countries and he will bring them back. That crime is rampant and there is going to be a stop put to it; that he is going to build a wall to keep the border secure; a border that has been one of worlds most peaceful; all to keep those who are willing to take work most Americans won't.

How many Americans do you know who will follow the crops work dawn to dusk and send a few Pesos home? Also when we look around, try and find a stone mason, or a gardener for $75 a month. When I was young it was the Japanese who did that, we knew who the rich were because their shrubs had bonsai trims.

This was not a speech of hope, of how we were going forward, it was how he is going to stop "This American Carnage." What American Carnage? He is going to stop Bangladesh from making cheaper clothing, the Japanese from making good quality cars at good prices. Is he going to bring back Delco that Romney's Bain Capital sold to China, nothing but appeals to prejudice and ignorance. He seems to believe he can alter the law of supply and demand, the mind of a megalomaniac, is now in charge of our country and its law forces, two out of five Americans believe him.

We are now going to see how conservative economics benefits us. Maybe you but not me. The GOP has begun their nihilistic campaign to destroy 80 years of progress all to satisfy an angry minority.

I did some apple picking one season- moving those heavy wooden ladders, and carrying the baskets we used was a challenge. The nimble, fast workers - Eastern Euro. background - outproduced me by about 300%.  It helps to experience jobs to appreciate the labor [ and laborers]involved.

CC, why do you use the epithet "elite" when you refer to people with high-functioning brains? Is it unfair of intellectuals to be smart when so many citizens go without? Should we give up some IQ points so you can have more?

And, by way, many of our jobs will never be replaced by AI or robotics. All of those that require thinking outside the box come to mind. (At least to mine, if not yours.)

From a humane perspective, i want to see those immigrants who have toiled here be allowed a path to citizenship. They were desperate for jobs - and used by all sorts of employers, from individual homeowners to huge developers - like Trump. But I also think that immigration reform should mean providing an enforced structure for immigration, with rules, including provision for speedy deportation to violators.

That said, the onus should be on employers who know - or deliberately refuse to know - to abide by labor laws. It WILL raise costs of everything from food to housing. Will it work its way out if more workers are employed at higher wages? I don't know- we are addicted to low cost products from countries that exploit workers -- undoubtedly every person commenting is using a Chinese made device right now. But some prices are probably unreasonably low compared to others - food, for instance. Would higher food prices mean pressure, say to lower home prices? Or just caused more hardship? I don't know.

I think Eric has written an extremely fair review if the type - and nice to see him publish more frequently.
In our home, we use very little wine and dislike most reds, save the odd braise. In our opinion, if a wine must be drunk, it will usually be a first-rate Riesling, served chilled (it will warm a little). With sincere apologies the huge clan of reds, often reported by Eric and others tooo be best-of-class, we began enjoying the dry whites of SW Germany, Alsace and Trier, FR areas many decades ago, and we know where/how to buy what we like. Far more volume goes into cooking fish and shellfish, but we will drink a little. When a locally assigned GI meets a local resident who grows grapes, miracles can happen. Forty-five years later, growing a few (100 acres) of Riesling-suitable" fruit seems to be our thing. The only wine that we make is processed via 100 or 250 gallon systems, both filled, corked and processed by hand. The other fruit is sold by weight/volume/bris, all with the understanding that our name man NEVER be used. It works. Some years produce world-class wine; others are best kept in the kitchen or cellar. Partner was born into the grape and wine business; I came only 45 years ago. In the end, we are grape farmers, not commercial wine makers. More than 90% of our harvest is sold to others. Guess who gets the first/last/best of the crop. And No. I won't grow the dense reds here. Did I mention Riesling? -Cg.

.
.
Off-topic observations of computer oddities:

Deb, this stuff has nothing to do with the crossword so if it's deleted, IMOK.

1. Your column URLs usually follow a predictable pattern involving posting date and column headline. Today, I expected it to be www.nytimes.com/2017/01/20/crosswords/how-ya-holding-up .

But for some reason, it is www.nytimes.com/2017/01/20/crosswords/how-ya-holding-up-macedonia-kavafi... . Odd.

2. This other thing could affect millions of people but I don't know if it's been publicized well, so I'm just giving people a heads-up. The US Gov't is messing with social media accounts, and many people will find themselves connected to an account to which they were not previously connected. For example, if someone were a Twitter "follower" of @realdonaldtrump, that user will now find herself following "@POTUS" as well [unless she searches through her "followed" accounts and deletes the one she wishes not to follow]. If someone else had been following "@POTUS" during the Obama Administration, he will now find himself following "@POTUS44" (one of Barack Obama's newly-assigned Twitter accounts); but he will still be following "@POTUS", which will no longer transmit Obama Tweets. There are endless permutations involving Facebook and other services, as well as FLOTUS, VP, VPOTUS, and similar accounts. "Likes", "follows", & similar connections will supposedly be generated.

So I'm just advising: People should check their social media accounts.

It happened when the Chargers moved from San Diego to Los Angeles--even to some Facebook pages that were not official. Most of the San Diego fans I know unliked the L.A. Chargers page right away.  First St. Louis then San Diego and maybe Oakland next.  I don't think these moves bode well for the future of the NFL.  Right now, I'm a Packers fan because I look forward to seeing them play above all the others.

.
I need to pick a new team. 46 years of never getting beyond the Conference Championship Game? Long enough.

The only team in my State would be the Bills. Can I root for a team that plays at "The Ralph"? No.

Packers are appealing but I prefer to choose a former AFL franchise. I'm an upstart like that!

What doesn't kill democracy strengthens it.

In the long run, Trump's "populism" will lead to a political uprising by We the People that will bury the Republicans and demagogues.

What does Trump know about "carnage?" He who is driven from fancy club to fancy club?

What did FDR know about the Great Depression? He was a billionaire (in inflated adjusted dollars), raised in privilege and from "old money".

What did JFK know about the working classes? LBJ? Carter? Clinton? None of them were poor. Al Gore and John Kerry were billionaires, but the DNC had no problem with THEM running for POTUS.

Doubtful. Today is the first full day of the Trump Dictatorship. Dictators always  figure out how to thwart 'consitutional safeguards.' Trump and his Republican 'sieg heilers' will run the US like Putin runs Russia and Erdogan runs Turkey. The two-term limit will be eliminated by Republican enablers; and voting will either be rigged or eliminated (... 'national emergency' of course) and Republicans willlove the new dictatorship, same as Russia's kleptocrats and docile citizens love Putin.

When he said "carnage" I immediately thought of the willful destruction in Scotland to build his golf course. While he was taking their land and destroying the environment, he was calling the people pigs, naming them individually by name and holding up his middle finger. ["You've Been Trumped", 2011 documentary]

You say Mr. Trump is taking aim at both billionaires and the government.  Knowing that he is planning to eliminate the estate tax, which affects only the truly wealthy and will cut government revenue, somehow I don't see it that way.

Your comment is well taken but at issue are only 5,200 estate across the country, which together will pay less than $20 billion. See http://www.taxpolicycenter.org/briefing-book/how-many-people-pay-estate-tax.

That legitimate reasons exist for eliminating "death taxes" is evidenced by the fact that New Hampshire, where you appear to reside, repealed its estate taxes in 2005.
The very small turnout appeared to unnerve our new Prez, family and staff. Instead of reaching out to all of us, he remained petty and arrogant. It will be a long four years for moat of us.

Agreed. In his first executive order, Trump directed government agencies to scale back as many aspects of the Affordable Care Act as possible….In broad language he gave federal agencies wide latitude to change, delay or waive provisions of the law that they deemed overly costly for insurers, drug makers, doctors, patients or states…essentially allowing the dismantling of the law to begin even before Congress moves to repeal it. He also directed HUD to suspend the FHA mortgage insurance rate cut President Obama signed into law to help first-time home buyers.  Trump's "American carnage" on the lower and middle class begins!

So definitely not Woodstockian. “In the event we are needed, we certainly will form a wall of meat,” promised Chris Cox, the founder of Bikers for Trump,

Ha!
More like Altamont than Woodstock. Except the performers at the Trumpaugural couldn't hold a candle to the Stones.
I was at Altamont, Owsley-ized. It was pretty intense, but nothing like what's happening in real life now.

Socrates: Language faux pas. NEVER call him "President" Trump.

Try Con Man Don, or Con Man Donald if you want to show him some respect or pity. But not "President." He'll never live up to the title, no matter how much he rants and raves about how great he is.

I can not remember buying anything of quality from Britain lately. Remodeling our kitchen, a Bosch oven, my little coffee grinder, 25 years old, a Braun, my electric shaver a Braun.

We do drive a Buick because i got the factory discount, the previous car was a Toyota, but i do have an F150. I had British cars and motorcycles over the years,they were distinguished by their tendency to leak oil. Somewhere I have a little essay by someone that describes how English vehicles had to leak oil in order to be able to run. Honda cured that.

A few fossils voted to take Britain out of the EU, hold overs from the 18th century, as in our Midwest red states a dislike of those foreigners who are taking American jobs. Well those jobs and those British jobs are going away, they are going to the rest of the world. they and us will have to pay more for their products, making us poorer, not richer.

I never had the leaking oil. my peeve was the headlamp system which was either "Off or Flicker".
I loved my little Spitfire 1500. I drove once every few months. Months because that's how long it was in the shop being repaired after my drive.

You clearly haven't ridden a modern British motorcycle in last 20yrs!!. They are well respected in Germany and sell very well in USA they are quality machines built in England most go for export. Also British R n D in racing like F1 ( including  NASCAR!) is a global export industry. Also all those digging and earth moving machines called JCBs that you see on building sites are made in UK.So maybe your fixtures are German but maybe your house was built with a product that wouldn't even be on your radar.

Erm, the wings were only built in Britain because of the single market. Airbus is essentially a French company and part of a larger European group. With Trump pushing the USAF to "buy American, hire American", May determined to hurl Britain out of the single market and the viability of the A380 itself as a commercial product being called into question, it's a particularly bad example of British industry. If I worked at the Broughton plant you're referring to, I'd be very nervous about my prospects! Airbus has no real reason to keep making A380 wings there, if at all. On the contrary, there's probably significant political pressure on the Airbus brass to *stop* manufacturing parts in the UK and bring the jobs back to EU countries.

Also, contrary to populist rhetoric, immigrants aren't sitting around in the south-east of England twiddling their thumbs and consuming services. They're there because there is lots of work and not enough English people to do it. They're mostly working and paying taxes. (In stark contrast to the hundreds of thousands of retired British seeking warmer climes in Spain and France. A great illustration of this is the *fact* that in 2014/15 the UK paid £700m to cover British expat healthcare and only received £50m back.) The uncomfortable truth is most immigrants will likely be asked to stay, because the UK needs them! So we make a political show of kicking them out, to please the racists, and then quietly allow them to stay because, frankly, we have to.

Wow is right. There is no way I could have watched. I thought back 8 years to when I skipped appointments so I could be part of (vicariously at home on my futon) the historic inauguration.

But today I chose to do something far more satisfying and useful than watching a racist, misogynist blabbermouth get sworn in. I went to the animal sanctuary and scooped litter boxes, mopped floors, and played with cats and kittens.

Susan,
I also did not watch today's inauguration. Any of it. My day was spent working, then coming home to my husband, loving on my dogs and then reading my current much loved John Grisham novel. Perfect day!
Well done on you for going to the shelter....thank you!
Maybe under this President you get to upgrade to a couch.
Think many people did not watch the inauguration.  I didn't; my sister didn't.  My sister observed whooping cranes, I shopped.

Don't let Trump and Company steal your happiness.

Resist. There is joy in it.
